metadata.feature_description: Process and render Markdown content in wiki articles

steps.action: Navigate to Wiki module and open article 'Markdown Test Article - Jan 2026'
steps.expected: Article content displays with wiki-style links rendered as HTML anchor tags
steps.actual: Wiki links like [[Published Article Test - Jan 2026]] are correctly rendered as clickable anchor tags with dnnSocialLink class

steps.action: Verify the simple wiki link syntax [[Subject]] is transformed to HTML
steps.expected: The [[Subject]] syntax should be replaced with Subject
steps.actual: Simple wiki links are correctly transformed - 'Published Article Test - Jan 2026' displays as a blue clickable link

steps.action: View article content with [[Title|Subject]] style links
steps.expected: Wiki links with custom titles should display the title text while linking to the subject
steps.actual: The link [[Click here for XSS Article|XSS Sanitization Test Article]] correctly displays as 'Click here for XSS Article' text linking to the XSS article

steps.action: Click on a wiki link rendered in article content
steps.expected: Navigation to the linked article or subject search page
steps.actual: Clicking on 'Published Article Test - Jan 2026' link navigated to /en-us/Community/Wiki/subject/Published%20Article%20Test%20-%20Jan%202026

observations: IMPORTANT: The 'Markdown Support' feature in this Wiki module is NOT standard CommonMark/GitHub-flavored Markdown. It specifically processes Wiki-style link syntax only.
Code review of MarkdownProcessor.cs (lines 40-44) confirms only two regex patterns are processed: [[Subject]] (SimpleTransform) and [[Title|Subject]] (ComplexTransform).
Standard Markdown syntax (# headers, **bold**, *italic*, - lists, ``` code blocks, | tables) is NOT processed by this module - these display as raw text.

The test article 'Markdown Test Article - Jan 2026' clearly demonstrates this: wiki-style links render correctly, while standard Markdown syntax like '# Header 1 Test' and '**bold text**' display as unprocessed text.
The EditorMode.cs file shows only Plaintext and Richtext modes exist - there is no dedicated 'Markdown mode' as suggested in the feature location.
The feature name 'Markdown Support' appears to be a misnomer - a more accurate name would be 'Wiki Link Processing' or 'Wiki-style Link Syntax'.
Links to non-existent articles are rendered with 'wiki-nonexistent-article' CSS class to visually distinguish them from existing article links.
